title: assignment1.qmd
text:
To Explain or to Predict? They talked about the relationship between causal explanation and empirical prediction. The some fields causal explanatory model has a high prediction power. While in empirical model like NLP the focus is on empirical prediction. The main hypothesis in this study is causal versus predictive distinction has high effect on statistical modeling process and its results. Explanatory modeling and predictive modeling reflect the data mining and statistical analysis methos to explain and predict. And modeling means the whole process including definition, study design, and data collection for statistical usage. In this study they define explaining as causal explanation and explanatory needling as the use of statistical models for testing causal explanations. Predictive modeling uses data mining algorithms and statistical models to predict future observations until time t+k. these modeling summarized the data structure. While in causal theory (descriptive modeling) rely on measurable model to describe the data, like a regression model is used to capture dependent and independent variables to show the relationships between variables. They consider four area for differences between explanation and prediction models, including : Causation-association: in explanatory model f represents causal relationship, while in predictive model f records correlation between inputs and outputs. Theory data: in explanatory, f model is created based on the theory to be able to explain while in predictive, the explanatory and clarity of model is in lower priority than data. Retrospective-prospective: in explanatory relies on testing the hypothesis of previous or current observation, while in prediction assumes the future observations. Bias-variance: in explanatory modeling we attempt on minimizing the bias to obtain more accurate representation. While in predictive models the try to maximize the combination of bias and estimation variance to reach improved empirical precision. These are the steps in the statistical modeling process: Define goal, design study and collect data, prepare data, eda, choose variables, choose methods, evaluate, validate, and model selection, use mode and report
They said consider both explanation power and prediction power as two dimension, as they are different qualities. There are some explanatory model have some level of predictive power to be considered scientifically useful and there are some predictive models have sufficient explanatory power to be scientifically useful. While , there exist predictive models that do not properly “explain” yet are scientifically valuable. (Bill Langford, Woit, 2006, pages x xii). Therefore, we should define our goal to optimize the right criteria and report both qualities to provide a complete picture of the model. Finally as statistics focuses on inference and less focus on predictive analysis, machine learning has been created.
Statistical modeling Two cultures One culture is data are generated by a given data model Second culture use algorithms and treats the data mechanism as unknown As statistical community relies on data models, it kept statisticians from working a large range of interesting problems. In the article Leo Brieman defines two goal in analyzing data. 1)prediction: predict future responses to future input variables 2) information: extract information about how nature connects response variables to input variables. He defines two different approaches toward the goals Data modeling cuture. It assumes a stocustic data model for inside of the black box. The value of parameters are estimated from data and model The algorithmic modeling culture. The inside of the box is unknown and an algorithmic operatrion can accurately predict. After several projects and statistical research he found that the belief in the infallibility of data models was almost religious. It is a strange phenomenon- once model created, it becomes truth and the conclusion from it are infallible. While it is not correct. When we make small changes in the model can change complete while it is accurate. He said the picture of which covariates are important can vary significantly between two models having about same deviance. Aggregate over a large set of competing models can reduce the non-uniqueness while improving accuracy He believes that statisticians should focus on solving the problem instead of asking what data model they can create. The best solution might ba algorithmic model or data model or combination of both. So they need to use wide variety of tools. The roots of statistics is lie on working with data and checking theory against data. And he hoped that this century our field will return t its toots.

Q1: Objective: Design prompts to conduct a structured systematic literature review on data mining and machine learning using multiple AI models (e.g. ChatGPT, Copilot, and Grok 3) and analyze each model’s contribution and refining prompts for academic precision and depth.
Step 1: initial prompt creation Task: Write a baseline prompt to request a structured systematic literature review on data mining and machine learning applications.
Context: I am a graduate student working on creating a structured literature review on data mining and machine learning applications Task: Conduct the structured literature review on data mining and machine learning application between 2012 to 2024 in the USA corporations.
Constraint: 1) just 2000 word with Academic word 2) include the strategy, hypothesis, tests and results. 3) Focus on data mining and machine learning 4) start it with recent years researches. 5) for each research write a paragraph including the hypothesis and summary of finding Format: Provide output as paragraphs with the result without bullet point.
Result: I compared DeepSeek, Gemini, and Copilot. the Copilot was the worst as it did not understood what I am talking and start with options when I select what I want again it did not create proper information and it was completely different from what I was asking.Deep Seek was good, it created more content for litreture review. In jeminy it provided short information about researches and it did not show the source of its research while Deepseek provided more information and the link for resources.
Step 2: Analyze Model Responses Structure: Deepseek provided more detail like the way that I asked it. it mentioned about the theory or hypothesis, It did not identify Gaps or meaningful things but it wrote it like a story from recent studies to later one with mentioning the name of the study and the person and year and the result of that study.while in the Geminy I did not see that much detail about studies and it just mentioned years but not taking about which article or which writer found these results.
Step 3: Refine the Prompt o Task: Revise the prompt to address deficiencies in each model’s response, creating three tailored prompts—one for ChatGPT, one for Copilot, and one for Grok 3.
Answer: for Copilot I will change it to: Context: I am a graduate student working on creating a structured literature review on data mining and machine learning applications Task: Conduct a 2000 word academic review on data mining and machine learning application in the USA corporate environement. Provide clear structured methodology section including search title, corporate industry focus, name of the writer and data evaluation metrics.
Constraint: 1) just 2000 word with Academic word 2) include the strategy, hypothesis, tests and results. 3) Focus on data mining and machine learning 4) start it with recent years researches. 5) mention the methodology strenght and weaknesses. , identify Gap and trends and hypothesis Format: Provide output as paragraphs with the result without bullet point.
I would put this for all three.
it now is mentioning all I want this time Copilot had a much better result than its first time and it provided separate paraghraphs for conclusion, methodology ,… so it was more complete even better than Deepseek and Gemini in the structure.but still it does not showing the resources that from which link it found these information. but the structure was better SO I understood that Gemini needs more synthetic structure and more details , deep seek needs more analytical guidance with separete constraints not all constraint in one line and I think Copilot needs both structure and more guidance
Step 4: Cross-Model Collaboration o Task: Integrate the best elements from each model’s output into a final systematic review. Write a new prompt for the student’s preferred model (e.g.,Grok 3) to synthesize the results.
Answer: Context: Produce 2000 word structured systemic litreture review, using the previously generated draft on data mining and machine learning applications in U.S corporations (2012-2024), synthesize the strongest structural organization, methodological clarity, analytically depth, documented trend analysis and hypothesis. constraints: Ensure the methodology section clearly specifies search strategy, industry scope and metrics for evaluation. Begin with the most recent studies. Present synthesized not individually summarized analysis of trends , corporate practices, hypotheses, tests, outcomes, methodology, gaps, weaknesses.
Format: use formal academic language show the review result in structured paragraphs without bullet points show who is the writer name and the title of their study at the beginning of the paragraph
Result: in Gemini I received a much better result, Copilot could not again provide the title of the resources, Deepseek did not provide a nice structured and it brings some chinees words in the middle of paragraphs but the content was good. the Gemini followed everything I asked and this is the result this is what I received from Gemini:
This systematic literature review synthesizes the evolution and application of data mining (DM) and machine learning (ML) within United States corporations from 2012 to 2024. The methodology employed for this review utilizes a PRISMA-based search strategy focused on the query “Machine Learning and Data Mining Applications in US Enterprise 2012-2024,” targeting high-impact journals in the Scopus and Web of Science databases. The industrial scope encompasses Finance, Healthcare, Retail, and Technology sectors, with data evaluation metrics primarily focused on predictive accuracy (F1-score, AUC-ROC), operational efficiency (ROI), and computational cost (latency/throughput).
The research of Eloundou, Manning, and Mishkin (2024) in their article The Dual Impact of Generative Artificial Intelligence on Corporate Employment and Valuation establishes the current paradigm of “Generative Augmentation” in US tech and service sectors. The authors hypothesize that Generative AI (GenAI) acts as a high-skill labor intensifier rather than a simple replacement tool, particularly for data-intensive roles like accounting and software engineering. Their tests, which aggregate task-based exposure across thousands of firm-level positions, reveal that post-ChatGPT (2022–2024), US firms with higher AI exposure saw increased average wages and initial valuation spikes. The finding indicates that while GenAI provides an average labor cost saving of 25%, the primary hurdle is a “realization gap” where firms struggle to translate potential productivity into tangible quarterly performance, identifying a critical trend toward organizational restructuring as a prerequisite for ML value.
In the healthcare and pharmaceutical sectors, Siva Sai et al. (2024) in The Transformative Impact of Generative AI across Industries: A Comprehensive Systematic Review examine the shift from diagnostic to generative applications. The researchers hypothesized that integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) would significantly accelerate drug discovery and medical imaging analysis in the US. By testing real-world scenarios in medical education and clinical diagnostics, the study found that GAN-based data mining could generate high-fidelity synthetic patient data, overcoming the privacy barriers of the HIPAA era. The outcome demonstrates that while diagnostic accuracy improved, the methodology’s weakness lies in “hallucination” risks and ethical biases, highlighting a research gap in regulatory frameworks for autonomous medical AI within US corporations.
Shifting to the 2020–2022 “Big Data Velocity” era, Uddin et al. (2023) in their review Recent Trends in Machine Learning for Healthcare Big Data Applications focus on the scalability of tree-based models and AutoML. Their central hypothesis suggested that feature set selection (FSS) is more critical for corporate efficiency than the choice of the neural network itself. By testing the Tree-based Pipeline Optimization Tool (TPOT) on large-scale RNA-Seq datasets, they found that TPOT-FSS completed tasks 17 times faster than standard models without sacrificing accuracy. This results in a summary of findings that emphasizes the “Green AI” trend, where US corporations are moving away from massive compute-heavy models toward computationally efficient, power-aware ML pipelines to meet sustainability goals.
Within the financial sector, Alshater et al. (2022) in Artificial Intelligence in Financial Market Prediction analyze the mid-period (2016–2019) transition toward deep reinforcement learning for stock market forecasting. The article hypothesizes that combining traditional data mining of historical prices with real-time sentiment analysis from social media would yield a statistically significant alpha in high-frequency trading. The tests, utilizing Random Forests and Gradient Boosting Machines, confirmed that multimodal data sources enhanced prediction accuracy by providing a “holistic perspective” on market sentiment. However, the study identifies a methodological weakness in “model drift,” where ML models trained on pre-pandemic data failed to generalize during the 2020 volatility, revealing a gap in the literature regarding “Robustness under Crisis” for corporate financial algorithms.
The foundational period of 2012–2015 is characterized by Chaudhary et al. (2016) in their synthesis of “Big Data Mining” in US retail. The hypothesis of this era was that moving from descriptive Business Intelligence (BI) to predictive data mining could reduce inventory overhead by 15% through more accurate demand forecasting. Tests performed on US retail giants using Hadoop and Spark frameworks showed that early ML models (SVM and Logistic Regression) were highly effective at detecting fraud and predicting churn, but were limited by the “siloed” nature of corporate data. This results in a summary of findings that points to the trend of “Data Democratization,” where the methodology’s strength was its ability to handle volume, but its weakness was a lack of real-time adaptability, a gap that was eventually filled by the streaming analytics of the late 2010s.
The synthesized trend analysis across the 2012–2024 spectrum reveals a clear trajectory from retrospective data mining to autonomous antigenic ML. The primary research gap identified is the “governance-efficiency paradox,” where the technical capacity for corporate automation outpaces the legal and ethical frameworks required to manage it. While current US corporate practices are moving toward “Small Language Models” (SLMs) and decentralized “Federated Learning” to protect data privacy, the literature shows a persistent weakness in the lack of longitudinal studies on AI’s impact on corporate culture and long-term skill degradation.
